articles.title: Portugees vs. Nederlands: De Belangrijkste Verschillen
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import ConjugationTable from '@components/ConjugationTable.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Portugees en Nederlands komen beide van Indo-Europese wortels, maar hebben heel verschillende ontwikkelingen doorgemaakt. Hier zijn de belangrijkste verschillen om op te letten!

## Taalfamilies

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Romaans vs. Germaans"
  translation="Portugees is een Romaanse taal, Nederlands is Germaans"

  context="Dit fundamentele verschil be√Ønvloedt alles!"
/>

| Kenmerk | Portugees | Nederlands |
|---------|-----------|------------|
| Taalfamilie | Romaans (Latijn) | Germaans |
| Verwante talen | Spaans, Italiaans, Frans | Duits, Engels, Zweeds |
| Geslachten | 2 (m/v) | 2 (de/het) |
| Werkwoordvervoegingen | Complex (6 vormen) | Relatief eenvoudig |

## Woordenschat: Latijnse Wortels

<VocabCard
  word="amor / noite / flor"
  translation="liefde / nacht / bloem"
  pronunciation="a-MOR / NOY-te / flor"
  example="Portugese woorden komen vaak van het Latijn."
/>

Sommige woorden lijken op hun Engelse equivalenten (via Frans/Latijn):

| Portugees | Nederlands | Engels |
|-----------|------------|--------|
| fam√≠lia | familie | family |
| na√ß√£o | natie | nation |
| situa√ß√£o | situatie | situation |
| telefone | telefoon | telephone |
| restaurante | restaurant | restaurant |

<CultureTip title="Leenwoorden" flag="üîÑ">
Door koloniale geschiedenis heeft Portugees woorden aan het Nederlands gegeven, zoals "fetisj" (feiti√ßo) en "cobra"!
</CultureTip>

## Grammatica: De Grote Verschillen

### 1. Werkwoordvervoegingen

Het GROOTSTE verschil! Portugees heeft zes verschillende vormen per tijd.

<VocabCard
  word="eu amo, tu amas, ele ama..."
  translation="ik hou van, jij houdt van, hij houdt van..."
  pronunciation="ew AH-mo, too AH-mash, EH-le AH-ma"
  example="Elke persoon heeft een andere uitgang!"
/>

| Persoon | Portugees (amar) | Nederlands (houden van) |
|---------|------------------|------------------------|
| ik | amo | hou (van) |
| jij | amas | houdt (van) |
| hij/zij | ama | houdt (van) |
| wij | amamos | houden (van) |
| jullie | amam | houden (van) |
| zij | amam | houden (van) |

**Nederlands:** 3-4 vormen per tijd
**Portugees:** 6 vormen per tijd + meerdere tijden!

### 2. Ser vs. Estar (Twee "Zijn"!)

<VocabCard
  word="Eu sou holand√™s / Eu estou feliz"
  translation="Ik ben Nederlands / Ik ben gelukkig"
  pronunciation="ew soh o-lan-DESH / ew esh-TOH fe-LEESH"
  example="Ser = permanent, Estar = tijdelijk"
/>

| Gebruik | Portugees | Nederlands |
|---------|-----------|------------|
| Nationaliteit | Eu **sou** holand√™s | Ik **ben** Nederlands |
| Emotie (nu) | Eu **estou** triste | Ik **ben** verdrietig |
| Locatie | Eu **estou** em Lisboa | Ik **ben** in Lissabon |
| Beroep | Eu **sou** professor | Ik **ben** leraar |

<CultureTip title="Ser of Estar?" flag="üí°">
Vuistregel: **Ser** = wie/wat je bent (karakter, nationaliteit). **Estar** = hoe/waar je bent (emoties, locatie).
</CultureTip>

### 3. Subjunctivo (Aanvoegende Wijs)

Portugees gebruikt de subjunctivo veel vaker dan Nederlands de aanvoegende wijs.

<VocabCard
  word="Espero que estejas bem"
  translation="Ik hoop dat je het goed maakt"
  pronunciation="esh-PE-ro ke esh-TE-zhash beng"
  example="Na 'espero que' volgt subjunctivo!"
/>

| Portugees | Nederlands |
|-----------|------------|
| Quero que venhas | Ik wil dat je komt |
| Espero que gostes | Ik hoop dat je het leuk vindt |
| Duvido que saiba | Ik betwijfel of hij/zij het weet |

### 4. Lidwoorden bij Namen

In het Portugees gebruik je vaak lidwoorden voor eigennamen!

<VocabCard
  word="Eu amo a Maria"
  translation="Ik hou van Maria"
  pronunciation="ew AH-mo a ma-REE-a"
  example="Het lidwoord 'a' wordt gebruikt bij namen!"
/>

| Portugees | Nederlands |
|-----------|------------|
| A Maria est√° aqui | Maria is hier |
| O Jo√£o telefonou | Jo√£o heeft gebeld |
| A Holanda √© bonita | Nederland is mooi |

## Uitspraak Verschillen

### Nasale Klanken

Portugees heeft nasale klanken die Nederlands niet heeft.

<VocabCard
  word="√£o / √µes / √£e"
  translation="Nasale klanken (uniek voor Portugees)"
  pronunciation="owng / oysh / aye"
  example="p√£o, cora√ß√µes, m√£e"
/>

| Geschreven | Uitspraak | Voorbeeld |
|------------|-----------|-----------|
| √£o | owng (nasaal) | cora√ß√£o, n√£o |
| √µes | oysh (nasaal) | cora√ß√µes |
| √£e | aye (nasaal) | m√£e, p√£es |
| im/em | ing/eng (nasaal) | sim, bem |

### De 'r' Klanken

<VocabCard
  word="carro vs. caro"
  translation="auto vs. duur"
  pronunciation="KA-ho vs. KA-ro"
  example="Dubbele 'rr' klinkt als een 'h'!"
/>

| Letter | Klank | Voorbeeld |
|--------|-------|-----------|
| r (begin) | h-achtig | rato (ha-to) |
| rr | h-achtig | carro (ka-ho) |
| r (midden/eind) | zachte r | caro, amor |

### De 'lh' en 'nh'

<VocabCard
  word="filho / vinho"
  translation="zoon / wijn"
  pronunciation="FEE-lyo / VEE-nyo"
  example="'lh' = lj, 'nh' = nj"
/>

## Woordvolgorde

### Bijvoeglijke Naamwoorden NA het Zelfstandig Naamwoord

<VocabCard
  word="uma casa grande / een groot huis"
  translation="groot huis (letterlijk: huis groot)"
  pronunciation="OO-ma KA-za GRAN-de"
  example="Het bijvoeglijk naamwoord komt ACHTER het zelfstandig naamwoord!"
/>

| Portugees | Nederlands |
|-----------|------------|
| uma mulher bonita | een mooie vrouw |
| um carro vermelho | een rode auto |
| a l√≠ngua portuguesa | de Portugese taal |

### Voornaamwoorden bij Werkwoorden

<VocabCard
  word="Amo-te / Te amo"
  translation="Ik hou van je"
  pronunciation="AH-mo-te / te AH-mo"
  example="Het voornaamwoord kan aan het werkwoord vastgeplakt worden!"
/>

| Portugees | Nederlands |
|-----------|------------|
| Amo-te | Ik hou van jou |
| Dou-te um beijo | Ik geef je een kus |
| Vejo-te amanh√£ | Ik zie je morgen |

## Handige Vergelijkingstabel

| Kenmerk | Portugees | Nederlands |
|---------|-----------|------------|
| Taalfamilie | Romaans | Germaans |
| Geslachten | 2 (o/a) | 2 (de/het) |
| Werkwoordvormen per tijd | 6 | 3-4 |
| "Zijn" werkwoorden | 2 (ser, estar) | 1 (zijn) |
| Subjunctivo | Veelgebruikt | Zeldzaam |
| Bijvoeglijk naamwoord | Na znw | Voor znw |
| Nasale klanken | Ja | Nee |

## Voordelen als Nederlander

1. **Latijnse leenwoorden** - Veel Nederlandse woorden komen via Frans/Latijn
2. **Bekende woordvolgorde in hoofdzinnen** - SVO structuur
3. **Geen naamvallen** - Net als in het Nederlands
4. **Twee geslachten** - Vergelijkbaar concept
5. **Logisch spellingsysteem** - Meestal fonetisch

## Meest Gemaakte Fouten

### 1. Ser en Estar Verwarren

<VocabCard
  word="FOUT: Eu sou feliz (nu)"
  translation="Moet zijn: Eu estou feliz"

  example="Emoties NU = estar, niet ser!"
/>

### 2. Bijvoeglijk Naamwoord voor Zelfstandig Naamwoord

<VocabCard
  word="FOUT: uma bonita mulher"
  translation="Moet zijn: uma mulher bonita"

  example="Het bijvoeglijk naamwoord komt ERNA!"
/>

### 3. Werkwoord Niet Vervoegen

<VocabCard
  word="FOUT: Ele amar"
  translation="Moet zijn: Ele ama"

  example="Het werkwoord MOET vervoegd worden!"
/>

### 4. Nasale Klanken Vergeten

<VocabCard
  word="FOUT: 'nao' uitspreken als 'nah-oh'"
  translation="Moet zijn: 'nowng' (nasaal)"

  example="De nasale klank is essentieel!"
/>

<CultureTip title="Oefening Baart Kunst" flag="üí™">
Het Portugese werkwoordsysteem is complex, maar met oefening wordt het vanzelfsprekend. Focus eerst op de tegenwoordige tijd!
</CultureTip>


## Tips voor Succes

1. **Leer werkwoorden systematisch** - Begin met de meest gebruikte
2. **Oefen de nasale klanken** - Luister en herhaal
3. **Onthoud: bijvoeglijk naamwoord achteraan** - Dit is anders dan Nederlands
4. **Oefen ser vs. estar** - Maak ezelsbruggetjes
5. **Luister veel** - Podcasts, muziek, Netflix met ondertiteling

## Snelle Geheugensteun

| Als je dit in NL zegt | Let op in het Portugees |
|----------------------|-------------------------|
| Ik ben blij (nu) | Estou feliz (niet sou!) |
| Een mooie vrouw | Uma mulher bonita (achteraan!) |
| Ik hou van je | Amo-te (werkwoord vervoegen!) |
| Nee | N√£o (nasale klank!) |

<CTA
  text="Klaar om de verschillen te overwinnen?"
  buttonText="Start met Portugees Leren"
/>

articles.title: I Love You in Spanish + 15 Phrases
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import ConjugationTable from '@components/ConjugationTable.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Learning to express love in Spanish opens up a world of romance and passion. Whether you're planning a trip to a Spanish-speaking country with your partner or simply want to add some romantic flair to your relationship, mastering these beautiful expressions of love will bring you closer together. Wondering [is Spanish hard to learn](/learn/en/es/is-spanish-hard-to-learn-a-romantic-journey-guide-for-couples/)? Good news - romantic phrases are a great way to start!

Spanish is known as one of the most romantic languages in the world, and for good reason. The way Spanish speakers express love is nuanced, passionate, and deeply meaningful. Let's explore the various ways to say "I love you" in Spanish and discover when to use each expression.

## The Two Main Ways to Say "I Love You" in Spanish

### Te Amo vs. Te Quiero

The most important distinction to understand is between **te amo** (I love you) and **te quiero** (I love you/I want you). While both translate to "I love you" in English, they carry different levels of intensity and meaning.

<VocabCard
  word="Te amo"
  translation="I love you (deeply, passionately)"
  pronunciation="[teh AH-moh]"
  example="Te amo con todo mi coraz√≥n - I love you with all my heart"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Te quiero"
  translation="I love you (affectionately)"
  pronunciation="[teh kee-EH-roh]"
  example="Te quiero mucho, mi amor - I love you very much, my love"
/>

<CultureTip title="Understanding the Difference" flag="üá™üá∏">
  In Spanish culture, "te amo" is reserved for deep, romantic love - typically used between spouses or long-term partners. "Te quiero" is more versatile and can be used with family, friends, or romantic partners. It's often the first "I love you" exchanged in Spanish relationships.
</CultureTip>

## Regional Variations and Formal Expressions

Spanish is spoken across many countries, and expressions of love can vary by region. Here are some beautiful alternatives you and your partner can learn:

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Te adoro"
  translation="I adore you"
  pronunciation="[teh ah-DOH-roh]"
  context="A passionate way to express deep affection, more intense than 'te quiero' but slightly less formal than 'te amo'"
/>

### Common Regional Variations

| Country/Region | Expression | Pronunciation | Meaning |
|---|---|---|---|
| Mexico | **Te quiero mucho** | [teh kee-EH-roh MOO-choh] | I love you very much |
| Argentina | **Te amo, mi vida** | [teh AH-moh mee VEE-dah] | I love you, my life |
| Spain | **Te quiero con locura** | [teh kee-EH-roh kohn loh-KOO-rah] | I love you madly |
| Colombia | **Eres mi todo** | [EH-rehs mee TOH-doh] | You are my everything |

## Conjugating the Verb "Amar" (To Love)

Understanding how to conjugate **amar** (to love) will help you express love to different people in various situations.

<ConjugationTable
  verb="amar"
  meaning="to love"
  conjugations={[
    { person: "I", word: "amo", translation: "I love" },
    { person: "You (informal)", word: "amas", translation: "you love" },
    { person: "He/She/You (formal)", word: "ama", translation: "he/she loves, you love" },
    { person: "We", word: "amamos", translation: "we love" },
    { person: "You all", word: "am√°is/aman", translation: "you all love" },
    { person: "They", word: "aman", translation: "they love" }
  ]}
/>

## Romantic Phrases for Couples to Practice

Here are additional romantic expressions that will make your Spanish conversations more heartfelt:

<VocabCard
  word="Eres el amor de mi vida"
  translation="You are the love of my life"
  pronunciation="[EH-rehs ehl ah-MOHR deh mee VEE-dah]"
  example="Siempre ser√°s el amor de mi vida - You will always be the love of my life"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Mi coraz√≥n es tuyo"
  translation="My heart is yours"
  pronunciation="[mee koh-rah-SOHN ehs TOO-yoh]"
  example="Desde el primer d√≠a, mi coraz√≥n es tuyo - From the first day, my heart is yours"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="No puedo vivir sin ti"
  translation="I can't live without you"
  pronunciation="[noh PWEH-doh vee-VEER seen tee]"
  example="Te necesito tanto, no puedo vivir sin ti - I need you so much, I can't live without you"
/>

### Terms of Endearment to Use Together

| Spanish Term | Pronunciation | English Meaning | When to Use |
|---|---|---|---|
| **Mi amor** | [mee ah-MOHR] | My love | Most common, safe for any stage |
| **Mi vida** | [mee VEE-dah] | My life | Very intimate, for serious relationships |
| **Mi cielo** | [mee see-EH-loh] | My sky/heaven | Sweet and romantic |
| **Coraz√≥n** | [koh-rah-SOHN] | Heart | Affectionate and warm |
| **Mi tesoro** | [mee teh-SOH-roh] | My treasure | Endearing and special |

<CultureTip title="Using Terms of Endearment" flag="üá™üá∏">
  Spanish speakers use terms of endearment very frequently, even in casual conversation. Don't be surprised to hear "mi amor" or "coraz√≥n" used between couples in everyday situations like asking what to have for dinner!
</CultureTip>

## Creative Ways to Express Love in Spanish

Beyond the basic "I love you," Spanish offers poetic ways to express your feelings:

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Eres mi media naranja"
  translation="You are my better half (literally: my half orange)"
  pronunciation="[EH-rehs mee MEH-dee-ah nah-RAHN-hah]"
  context="A uniquely Spanish expression meaning you complete me, like two halves of an orange"
/>

### Poetic Expressions for Advanced Learners

- **"Eres la luz de mis ojos"** [EH-rehs lah loos deh mees OH-hohs] - You are the light of my eyes
- **"Contigo hasta el fin del mundo"** [kohn-TEE-goh AHS-tah ehl feen dehl MOON-doh] - With you until the end of the world
- **"Eres mi raz√≥n de ser"** [EH-rehs mee rah-SOHN deh sehr] - You are my reason for being

## Practice Exercises for Couples

### Daily Practice Routine

1. **Morning Affirmations**: Start each day by saying "Buenos d√≠as, mi amor" and one expression from this article
2. **Text Messages**: Send each other romantic Spanish phrases throughout the day
3. **Evening Conversations**: Practice conjugating "amar" and "querer" with different subjects
4. **Role-Playing**: Create scenarios where you'd use different levels of "I love you"

### Conversation Starters

- "¬øCu√°ndo supiste que me quer√≠as?" - When did you know you loved me?
- "¬øQu√© significa el amor para ti?" - What does love mean to you?
- "Cu√©ntame sobre tu primera impresi√≥n de m√≠" - Tell me about your first impression of me

<CultureTip title="Romance in Spanish Culture" flag="üá™üá∏">
  Spanish-speaking cultures tend to be very expressive about love and affection. Public displays of affection are common, and people aren't shy about expressing their feelings verbally. This openness makes Spanish an incredibly rich language for romantic expression.
</CultureTip>

## When to Use Each Expression

Timing is everything when it comes to expressing love in Spanish:

- **First few months**: Stick with "te quiero" and terms of endearment like "mi amor"
- **Serious relationship**: "Te amo" becomes appropriate when you feel deep, committed love
- **Married couples**: All expressions are fair game, with "te amo" being the standard
- **Family context**: "Te quiero" is perfect for family members

## Making It Memorable

To help you and your partner remember these beautiful expressions:

1. **Create flashcards** with Spanish on one side, English and pronunciation on the other
2. **Set phone reminders** to practice one new phrase daily
3. **Watch Spanish romantic movies** together to hear these phrases in context
4. **Listen to Spanish love songs** and identify the expressions you've learned

Mastering these expressions of love in Spanish will not only improve your language skills but also add a new dimension of romance to your relationship. Remember, the key to authentic pronunciation and usage is practice, so don't be afraid to use these phrases with each other daily.

Whether you choose the passionate intensity of "te amo" or the warm affection of "te quiero," you're now equipped with the tools to express your love beautifully in Spanish. ¬°Que viva el amor!

## Continue Your Spanish Love Journey

- **[Spanish Pet Names](/learn/en/es/spanish-pet-names-for-couples-25-romantic-terms-of-endearment-to-learn-together/)** - 25 terms of endearment
- **[Spanish Compliments](/learn/en/es/spanish-compliments-for-couples-50-romantic-phrases-to-flatter-your-partner/)** - 50 romantic phrases
- **[Spanish Pronunciation Guide](/learn/en/es/spanish-pronunciation-guide-for-couples-master-the-sounds-of-love-together/)** - Master the sounds
- **[Spanish Verb Conjugation](/learn/en/es/spanish-verb-conjugation-basics-for-couples-learn-together-with-love/)** - Grammar basics
- **[Meeting Spanish Family](/learn/en/es/meeting-your-spanish-partners-family-essential-phrases-for-couples-to-master-together/)** - Family visit essentials

  text="Ready to master Spanish with your partner? Practice with AI voice chat, save phrases to your Love Log, and your partner can be your tutor. Perfect for bilingual couples!"
  buttonText="Start Learning Now"
/>

articles.title: 100 Most Common German Words
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import ConjugationTable from '@components/ConjugationTable.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Learning the most common words in any language gives you the biggest return on your effort. Studies show that the 100 most frequent words make up about 50% of everyday speech! Master these essential German words with your partner, and you'll understand half of what you hear and read.

## Why Start with Common Words?

When learning German together, focusing on high-frequency words helps you:
- Understand more of what you hear immediately
- Start building simple sentences quickly
- Feel confident in basic conversations
- Recognize words in authentic German content

<CultureTip title="The Power of Frequency" flag="üá©üá™">
The word "und" (and) alone accounts for about 3% of all German words used! Learning these 100 words gives you a solid foundation that makes learning everything else easier.
</CultureTip>

## Articles and Pronouns (1-20)

<VocabCard
  word="der, die, das"
  translation="the (masculine, feminine, neuter)"
  pronunciation="[dehr, dee, dahs]"
  example="der Mann, die Frau, das Kind"
/>

### The Basics

| # | German | English | Pronunciation |
|---|--------|---------|---------------|
| 1 | der | the (masc.) | [dehr] |
| 2 | die | the (fem./pl.) | [dee] |
| 3 | das | the (neut.) | [dahs] |
| 4 | ein | a/an (masc./neut.) | [ine] |
| 5 | eine | a/an (fem.) | [AI-neh] |
| 6 | ich | I | [ikh] |
| 7 | du | you (informal) | [doo] |
| 8 | er | he | [air] |
| 9 | sie | she/they/you (formal) | [zee] |
| 10 | es | it | [es] |

<VocabCard
  word="wir"
  translation="we"
  pronunciation="[veer]"
  example="Wir lernen zusammen Deutsch - We're learning German together"
/>

| # | German | English | Pronunciation |
|---|--------|---------|---------------|
| 11 | wir | we | [veer] |
| 12 | ihr | you (plural informal) | [eer] |
| 13 | mein | my | [mine] |
| 14 | dein | your (informal) | [dine] |
| 15 | sein | his/its | [zine] |
| 16 | ihr | her/their | [eer] |
| 17 | unser | our | [OON-zer] |
| 18 | dieser | this | [DEE-zer] |
| 19 | jeder | every/each | [YAY-der] |
| 20 | man | one/you (general) | [mahn] |

## Essential Verbs (21-40)

<VocabCard
  word="sein"
  translation="to be"
  pronunciation="[zine]"
  example="Ich bin gl√ºcklich mit dir - I am happy with you"
/>

| # | German | English | Pronunciation |
|---|--------|---------|---------------|
| 21 | sein | to be | [zine] |
| 22 | haben | to have | [HAH-ben] |
| 23 | werden | to become/will | [VEHR-den] |
| 24 | k√∂nnen | can/to be able | [KER-nen] |
| 25 | m√ºssen | must/to have to | [MUE-sen] |
| 26 | sagen | to say | [ZAH-gen] |
| 27 | machen | to make/do | [MAH-khen] |
| 28 | gehen | to go | [GAY-en] |
| 29 | wissen | to know (fact) | [VIS-sen] |
| 30 | kommen | to come | [KOM-men] |

<VocabCard
  word="lieben"
  translation="to love"
  pronunciation="[LEE-ben]"
  example="Ich liebe dich - I love you"
/>

| # | German | English | Pronunciation |
|---|--------|---------|---------------|
| 31 | wollen | to want | [VOL-len] |
| 32 | sollen | should/to be supposed to | [ZOL-len] |
| 33 | sehen | to see | [ZAY-en] |
| 34 | geben | to give | [GAY-ben] |
| 35 | nehmen | to take | [NAY-men] |
| 36 | finden | to find | [FIN-den] |
| 37 | denken | to think | [DEN-ken] |
| 38 | stehen | to stand | [SHTAY-en] |
| 39 | lassen | to let/leave | [LAH-sen] |
| 40 | bleiben | to stay | [BLY-ben] |

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Bleib bei mir"
  translation="Stay with me"
  pronunciation="[blyb by meer]"
  context="A romantic way to ask your partner to stay close."
/>

## Prepositions and Conjunctions (41-60)

<VocabCard
  word="und"
  translation="and"
  pronunciation="[oont]"
  example="Du und ich - You and I"
/>

| # | German | English | Pronunciation |
|---|--------|---------|---------------|
| 41 | und | and | [oont] |
| 42 | in | in | [in] |
| 43 | zu | to | [tsoo] |
| 44 | mit | with | [mit] |
| 45 | von | from/of | [fon] |
| 46 | f√ºr | for | [fuer] |
| 47 | auf | on | [owf] |
| 48 | an | at/on | [ahn] |
| 49 | bei | at/with | [by] |
| 50 | nach | after/to | [nahkh] |

<VocabCard
  word="mit dir"
  translation="with you"
  pronunciation="[mit deer]"
  example="Ich gehe mit dir - I'm going with you"
/>

| # | German | English | Pronunciation |
|---|--------|---------|---------------|
| 51 | aus | from/out of | [ows] |
| 52 | √ºber | over/about | [UE-ber] |
| 53 | aber | but | [AH-ber] |
| 54 | oder | or | [OH-der] |
| 55 | wenn | when/if | [ven] |
| 56 | als | when/as/than | [ahls] |
| 57 | dass | that (conjunction) | [dahs] |
| 58 | weil | because | [vile] |
| 59 | denn | because/for | [den] |
| 60 | durch | through | [doorkh] |

## Common Nouns (61-80)

<VocabCard
  word="die Liebe"
  translation="love"
  pronunciation="[dee LEE-beh]"
  example="Die Liebe ist wunderbar - Love is wonderful"
/>

| # | German | English | Pronunciation |
|---|--------|---------|---------------|
| 61 | die Zeit | time | [dee tsyte] |
| 62 | das Jahr | year | [dahs yahr] |
| 63 | der Tag | day | [dehr tahk] |
| 64 | die Woche | week | [dee VOH-kheh] |
| 65 | der Mann | man | [dehr mahn] |
| 66 | die Frau | woman | [dee frow] |
| 67 | das Kind | child | [dahs kint] |
| 68 | das Haus | house | [dahs hows] |
| 69 | die Arbeit | work | [dee AR-byte] |
| 70 | das Leben | life | [dahs LAY-ben] |

<VocabCard
  word="das Herz"
  translation="heart"
  pronunciation="[dahs herts]"
  example="Mein Herz geh√∂rt dir - My heart belongs to you"
/>

| # | German | English | Pronunciation |
|---|--------|---------|---------------|
| 71 | die Welt | world | [dee velt] |
| 72 | das Wort | word | [dahs vort] |
| 73 | die Hand | hand | [dee hahnt] |
| 74 | das Auge | eye | [dahs OW-geh] |
| 75 | der Kopf | head | [dehr kopf] |
| 76 | die Stadt | city | [dee shtaht] |
| 77 | das Land | country | [dahs lahnt] |
| 78 | der Weg | way/path | [dehr vayk] |
| 79 | die Nacht | night | [dee nahkht] |
| 80 | das Herz | heart | [dahs herts] |

<CultureTip title="Gender Matters" flag="üá©üá™">
Notice that every German noun has a gender (der, die, das). Learning the article with the noun from the start saves time later. Make flashcards with the article included: "die Liebe" not just "Liebe."
</CultureTip>

## Adjectives and Adverbs (81-95)

<VocabCard
  word="gut"
  translation="good/well"
  pronunciation="[goot]"
  example="Du bist so gut zu mir - You are so good to me"
/>

| # | German | English | Pronunciation |
|---|--------|---------|---------------|
| 81 | gut | good | [goot] |
| 82 | sch√∂n | beautiful | [shern] |
| 83 | gro√ü | big/tall | [grohs] |
| 84 | klein | small | [kline] |
| 85 | neu | new | [noy] |
| 86 | alt | old | [ahlt] |
| 87 | lang | long | [lahng] |
| 88 | viel | much/many | [feel] |
| 89 | ganz | whole/entirely | [gahnts] |
| 90 | sehr | very | [zehr] |

<VocabCard
  word="immer"
  translation="always"
  pronunciation="[IM-mer]"
  example="Ich liebe dich immer - I love you always"
/>

| # | German | English | Pronunciation |
|---|--------|---------|---------------|
| 91 | immer | always | [IM-mer] |
| 92 | noch | still/yet | [nokh] |
| 93 | schon | already | [shohn] |
| 94 | nur | only | [noor] |
| 95 | jetzt | now | [yetst] |

## Question Words and Others (96-100)

<VocabCard
  word="was"
  translation="what"
  pronunciation="[vahs]"
  example="Was machst du? - What are you doing?"
/>

| # | German | English | Pronunciation |
|---|--------|---------|---------------|
| 96 | was | what | [vahs] |
| 97 | wer | who | [vehr] |
| 98 | wie | how | [vee] |
| 99 | wo | where | [voh] |
| 100 | warum | why | [vah-ROOM] |

## Practice Sentences Using Common Words

Now let's combine these words into useful sentences:

<VocabCard
  word="Ich bin mit dir gl√ºcklich"
  translation="I am happy with you"
  pronunciation="[ikh bin mit deer GLUEK-likh]"
  example="Using: ich, sein, mit, dir"
/>

### More Practice Sentences

| German | English | Words Used |
|--------|---------|------------|
| Wir gehen nach Hause | We're going home | wir, gehen, nach |
| Ich denke an dich | I'm thinking of you | ich, denken, an |
| Du bist sehr sch√∂n | You are very beautiful | du, sein, sehr, sch√∂n |
| Wir haben viel Zeit | We have a lot of time | wir, haben, viel, Zeit |
| Ich will immer bei dir sein | I want to always be with you | ich, wollen, immer, bei, sein |

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Du bist das Beste in meinem Leben"
  translation="You are the best in my life"
  pronunciation="[doo bist dahs BES-teh in MY-nem LAY-ben]"
  context="Using common words to express deep feelings."
/>

## Tips for Learning These Words

### 1. Learn in Context
Don't just memorize isolated words. Learn them in phrases and sentences that are meaningful to your relationship.

### 2. Practice Daily
Review 10-15 words per day with your partner. Quiz each other during meals or walks.

### 3. Use Spaced Repetition
Review words at increasing intervals: after 1 day, 3 days, 7 days, 14 days.

### 4. Make it Personal
Create sentences about your life together using these words.

### 5. Label Your Home
Put sticky notes on items around your house with German words.

## Practice Activities for Couples

### Activity 1: Daily Word Challenge
Each day, pick 5 words from this list. Use each one in a sentence about your day.

### Activity 2: Story Time
Take turns creating a short story using only words from this list. See how creative you can get!

### Activity 3: Word Association
One person says a German word, the other responds with a related word in German.

### Activity 4: Translation Race
Take turns translating sentences using these words. Time each other!

<CultureTip title="Building Blocks" flag="üá©üá™">
These 100 words are your building blocks. Once you know them well, German content becomes more accessible. You'll start recognizing words everywhere - in songs, movies, and conversations. Keep adding new words while maintaining these fundamentals!
</CultureTip>

## Quick Reference Chart

| Category | Words to Know |
|----------|--------------|
| Being | sein, haben, werden |
| Doing | machen, gehen, kommen |
| Thinking | denken, wissen, finden |
| Connecting | und, oder, aber, weil |
| Locating | in, auf, bei, nach |
| Describing | gut, sch√∂n, gro√ü, viel |
| Questioning | was, wer, wie, wo, warum |
| Timing | jetzt, immer, noch, schon |

## Your Next Steps

Master these 100 words, and you've built a solid foundation. You'll understand more German immediately and be ready to add specialized vocabulary for your interests. Learning together makes it easier - quiz each other, celebrate progress, and use these words in your daily conversations.

Remember: Consistency beats intensity. Ten minutes daily is better than one hour weekly. Start today!

<CTA text="Ready to master essential German vocabulary?" buttonText="Start Learning Now" />
